p.text: Counsel for the defendant has submitted that I ought not to allow the plaintiff to reopen his case despite the fact that he disclaims that the evidence will cause his client any embarrassment or prejudice. The essential principle which I should apply in relation to the application is that I should do justice as between the parties. The fact that the defendant disclaims any prejudice is an important consideration. Some of the cases, however, say that a party ought not be allowed to reopen if the evidence sought to be led was available to him at the time of the trial and an apparently conscious decision was made not to lead it. The evidence sought to be led came from depositions taken at a coroner's inquest. These were in court during the trial and photographs taken by the police and tendered before the coroner were tendered by counsel for the plaintiff. He does not resist the suggestion that he was well aware of the evidence to which I have referred during the trial. As was said by Wolff CJ in Watson v Metropolitan (Perth) Passenger Transport Trust [1965] WAR 88 at 89 , “there is a dearth of authority as to the circumstances in which the court should reopen the evidence after the trial has concluded”. In Murray v Figge (1974) 4 ALR 612 , Muirhead J sitting as a judge of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory collected the cases decided upon this question in Australia. Apart from Watson’s case 1 referred to above he cited Hughes v Hill [1937] SASR 285 and Betts v Wittingslowe (No 1) [1944] SASR 163 . Muirhead J did not refer to the decision of Romer J (as he then was) in Barker v Furlong [1891] 2 Ch 172 at 184.

Not overlooking that the prime consideration is the due administration of justice, it would seem to me that the Australian judges have tended to ask themselves the question whether the evidence sought to be led upon a reopening was not led either because it did not become known to the plaintiff's legal advisers, either before or during the presentation of the plaintiff's case, or because counsel inadvertently omitted to lead it. In Hughes v Hill, 2above, Cleland J decided that to allow a party to reopen a case in order to lead evidence which he had consciously decided not to lead in the course of his case “would form an evil and dangerous precedent”. He then referred to some of what Romer J said in Barker v Furlong, 3above, at the pages earlier mentioned.

It is curious to me that such law as there is on this subject has tended to develop in quite a different way from the law which indicated to a judge, faced with an application to amend pleadings, the manner in which his discretion should be exercised. Broadly speaking any amendment should be allowed, unless the embarrassment thus caused the opposite party cannot be cured by an adjournment and costs.

A reading of the judgment of Romer J in Barker v Furlong shows that it was a very different type of case from the present. It further shows that his Lordship did not, in deciding what he should do, take the severe view expressed by Cleland J in the words above cited. Barker v Furlong was a case where counsel for a plaintiff was conscious that there might be said to be a gap in his proof when he closed his case. He thought that he could have remedied the situation, if indeed it existed, by calling the defendant who was in court. He decided not to do so because he thought that the defendant would be called by his own counsel and he would have the benefit of cross-examining him. Romer J refused an application to reopen for the purpose of calling the defendant when counsel for the defendant announced that he did not propose to call his client. Having referred to the above circumstances, his Lordship at 184 continued:

This being so, it appeared to me that the plaintiff's counsel had, in the exercise of his judgment, preferred to close his case without calling the defendant on the chance that the defendant would appear in the box to support his own case, when he could be cross-examined without the risk attending the calling of him as one of the plaintiff's witnesses; and it appeared to me that in a case like this, in granting the plaintiff's application after the defendant's case had been argued and closed and a reply begun, I should be making a precedent which would, if established, lead to an improper amount of laxity in the conduct of a plaintiff's case.

The last words of his Lordship are important and perhaps led Cleland J in Hughes v Hill , above, to say what he did. I think that in 1976, more so perhaps than in 1891, it is realised that those who suffer from laxity in the presentation of a case are not counsel whose laxity it is that is referred to, but clients who have, where that laxity occurs, no redress. I think in arriving at a conclusion as to what I should do I must take very much into account the need to ensure that cases are properly presented and, further, that if risks are taken by counsel consciously, strong reasons must be shown why their clients are, after all, to have a second chance. But I must also take into account the fact that the defendant in this case has expressly disclaimed that any prejudice will be occasioned to it by allowing the evidence in. If, for example, as I thought the position at one stage was, counsel for the defendant had expected the evidence as to alcohol to be called and was then proposing himself to call evidence, perhaps from Miss Clarke, I would certainly have refused the application if Miss Clarke could not have been found. But that position was the one which counsel for the defendant expressly disclaimed. In those circumstances, and notwithstanding what has been said in other Australian cases on this subject, I am of opinion that I should admit the evidence in the plaintiff's case and I do so.
Watson v Metropolitan (Perth) Passenger Transport Trust [1965] WAR 88 .
